text:
Thanks, yeah I’m hoping to have something to interact with and share before the end of the month, . But if you’ve ever used the fugitive.vim’s `Glog` command to move forward and back through a file’s history, I think its possible to break that apart and have interactive visualizations where you can move forward and back at the project/file level, the class level, the function level and maybe even find ways to drop into an interactive session for any of those pieces. One idea I have is using code coverage tools to get a list of tests that touch a specific function, and then being able to start a debugger session at a particular spot at a particular point in time in the project’s history with the test taking care of all the setup for you.

Essentially all the information you need is there in the git history of the project, and I think if you combine it with a few different tools and focus your interface/UX to the use case of reading/understanding code, there’s something there :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Hi, I contribute to the game engine Godot Engine.  We cater to the surface level understanding of the game designers who barely code, to the gameplay developers who care about games than the complexity of a rendering engine, to the game engine developers who have to provide understanding of all the cases but don't have bandwidth to dedicate to being a gameplay developer.

In Godot Engine, we have several coding interfaces. C++ core, C++ as a shared library GDNative, GDScript which is a custom python-like game script,  and Visual Script which is a Node and Wire graphical editor. <https://godotengine.org/>

I and a Google summer of code student have been improving Visual Script from it's current unusable state. <https://godotengine.org/article/gsoc-2019-progress-report-3#visual-scripting> The work has been done, but it's not fully merged yet. Godot Engine is not just capable of games, imagine using a single executable editor / game for other things!

attachments.title: GSoC 2019 progress report #3
attachments.text: For the second time, Godot took part in the Google Summer of Code (GSoC) programme, which lets students from all over the world work for three months on specific projects thanks to a Google stipend. We had 8 students working for on great new features all around the engine, and in this third and last progress report, they outline the final state of their GSoC work, how to use it (when relevant) and future steps that they might envision for the feature they worked on.

elements.text:

We cater to the surface level understanding of the game designers who barely code, to the gameplay developers who care about games than the complexity of a rendering engine, to the game engine developers who have to provide understanding of all the cases but don't have bandwidth to dedicate to being a gameplay developer.

In Godot Engine, we have several coding interfaces. C++ core, C++ as a shared library GDNative, GDScript which is a custom python-like game script,  and Visual Script which is a Node and Wire graphical editor.
I and a Google summer of code student have been improving Visual Script from it's current unusable state.
The work has been done, but it's not fully merged yet. Godot Engine is not just capable of games, imagine using a single executable editor / game for other things!

text: Hope to join the community, and maybe improve what Godot Engine has even more!

text: Hey there, I'm Jacob. Have been curious about languages for a long time, and programming languages for a slightly shorter amount of time. Not particularly formally educated in either area, but I do enjoy poking around PL environments. Smug Lisp weenie (without a job in Lisp though, so as a hobby only), but I've also been very influenced by my experiences in Smalltalk. Would like to build more environments and less apps, but preferably without inventing a language of my own.

elements.text: Hey there, I'm Jacob. Have been curious about languages for a long time, and programming languages for a slightly shorter amount of time. Not particularly formally educated in either area, but I do enjoy poking around PL environments. Smug Lisp weenie (without a job in Lisp though, so as a hobby only), but I've also been very influenced by my experiences in Smalltalk. Would like to build more environments and less apps, but preferably without inventing a language of my own.

text: Hi! Saw the catalogue post on HN and found it super interesting :slightly_smiling_face: I'm one of the cofounders of <https://withkoji.com> , a web-based IDE + hosting platform trying to make it easier for non-devs and junior devs to create games and web apps (JS or JS-flavored things) by remixing existing apps and then using a combination of code and no-code interfaces to create something new. We're fresh out of beta, and already have a ton of different people from all around the world and all walks of life creating all kinds of weird things -- the goal is to do to app development what YouTube did to video publishing. Some more info here: <https://venturebeat.com/2019/04/23/gometa-raises-6-million-and-launches-koji-web-app-development-platform/> and here: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BgpFGMH6VR4> (long technical video). Anyway, excited to have found this community and look forward to participating more!

attachments.title: Pick an app, remix, launch - Koji
attachments.text: Koji is an app development platform that lets anyone create apps and games. Find something you like, remix it, and share it with the world.
attachments.fallback: Koji: Pick an app, remix, launch - Koji

attachments.title: GoMeta raises $6 million and launches Koji web app development platform
attachments.text: GoMeta is announcing it has raised $6 million and is launching Koji, a new development platform that makes it faster for devs to build web apps.
attachments.fallback: VentureBeat: GoMeta raises $6 million and launches Koji web app development platform

text: Koji is framework/engine agnostic, as long as whatever you’re writing runs on web. So it’s not a programming language or an engine, more of a tool like replit or glitch. A lot of the popular games on that trending page were created using p5, so those ones are 2d, but that’s simply a function of having had a lot of p5 devs show up and play with the platform early on

elements.text: Koji is framework/engine agnostic, as long as whatever you’re writing runs on web. So it’s not a programming language or an engine, more of a tool like replit or glitch. A lot of the popular games on that trending page were created using p5, so those ones are 2d, but that’s simply a function of having had a lot of p5 devs show up and play with the platform early on

text: Koji projects are code + template configuration files that render visual controls. We decided to take this hybrid approach after some learnings from our other project, metaverse studio, which is a data-flow drag and drop building for creating augmented reality experiences, more in line with the visual novel type things you mentioned: <https://studio.gometa.io>

attachments.title: Metaverse Studio
attachments.text: Metaverse is the easiest way to create Augmented Reality experiences. No programming required.

elements.text: Koji projects are code + template configuration files that render visual controls. text: I've been working on a visual script interface but it's not as good as the primary 3d game engines.. unity and ue4. I think the future of programming is allowing more accessible interfaces to the same engine. So I'm curious how your vision of the future of coding is. I noticed that Koji projects are standard web projects with git and javascript source. That doesn't sound like the future. We've been floating ideas imagining the entire editor was web based and using visual scripting with the editor.

text: Koji solves an incredible of very difficult problems that programmers are faced with. It is a very commendable project, one of best i have seen in a long time. Just handling recertification for free using the certs that you renew every 30 days saves people a lot of money (several hundred dollars for code signing certs from most companies, because there is a monopoly now with all the acquisitions of certificate issuing authorities). Trying to develop inside a browser with the inability to write the local hard drive makes software development almost impossible, so their connection to a server spun up from a pool is very clever.  I made a lot of iphone apps, and waiting 2 weeks for approval, not to mention the $99/year is an impediment of sorts.

text: the one thing i don't like about it is that you are using JS as the coding language. JS is not a good programming language. It is full of traps for the unwary. Anyway Koji allows people to use so many services that would take months to learn, so in that sense it is a return to a gentler time.
